meanings.def: towards or in a higher position
examples: He jumped up from his chair.
Your mum said you were up here (= upstairs).
The sun was already up (= had risen) when they set off.
They live up in the mountains.
It didn't take long to put the tent up.
You look nice with your hair up (= arranged on top of or at the back of your head).
Lay the cards face up (= facing upwards) on the table.
Up you come! (= said when lifting a child)
The car was up on blocks.
I was up on deck at first light.
Two men were up on the roof, repairing a leak.
I pinned the notice up on the wall.
She tries to stay under water but she floats back up.

meanings.def: to or at a higher level
examples: She turned the volume up.
Prices are still going up (= rising).
United were 3–1 up at half-time.
The wind is getting up (= blowing more strongly).
Sales are well up on last year.
Student numbers in English language schools in this country increased from 66 000 in 2018 to just over 84 000 in 2019.
The number of students increased by almost 30 per cent compared with the previous year.
Student numbers shot up/increased dramatically in 2019.
The proportion of Spanish students rose sharply from 5 per cent in 2018 to 14 per cent in 2019.
There was a significant rise in student numbers in 2019.
The 2019 figure was 84 000, an increase of 28 per cent on the previous year.
The 2019 figure was 84 000, 28 per cent up on the previous year.
As the chart shows, this can partly be explained by a dramatic increase in students from Spain.

meanings.def: to the place where somebody/something is
examples: A car drove up and he got in.
She went straight up to the door and knocked loudly.

meanings.def: out of bed
examples: I stayed up late (= did not go to bed until late) last night.
(British English) He's up and about again after his illness.

meanings.def: to or at an important place, especially a large city
examples: We're going up to New York for the day.
(British English, formal) His son's up at Oxford (= Oxford University).

meanings.def: to a place in the north of a country; further north than somewhere else
examples: They've moved up north.
We drove up to Inverness to see my father.
I'm up there almost every other weekend
Up here in Liverpool things are different.

meanings.def: completely
examples: We ate all the food up.
The stream has dried up.

meanings.def: so as to be finished or closed
examples: I have some paperwork to finish up.
Do your coat up; it's cold.

meanings.def: into pieces or parts
examples: She tore the paper up.
They've had the road up (= with the surface broken or removed) to lay some pipes.
How shall we divide up the work?

meanings.def: so as to be formed or brought together
examples: The government agreed to set up a committee of inquiry.
She gathered up her belongings.

meanings.def: finished; over
examples: Time's up. Stop writing and hand in your papers.

meanings.def: used to say that something is happening, especially something unusual or unpleasant
examples: I could tell something was up by the looks on their faces.
What's up? (= What is the matter?)
What's up with him? He looks furious.
Is anything up? You can tell me.

meanings.def: about to happen, be discussed, etc.
examples: Next up in our top ten is a new release by Ariana Grande.
Up after the break we will be introducing our mystery guest!

meanings.def: to be somebody’s duty or responsibility; to be for somebody to decide
examples: It's not up to you to tell me how to do my job.
Shall we eat out or stay in? It's up to you.

meanings.def: to be of poor quality; to not be very good
examples: His work isn't up to much.

meanings.def: facing problems or opposition
examples: Teachers are up against some major problems these days.
She's really up against it (= in a difficult situation).

meanings.def: moving upwards and downwards
examples: The boat bobbed up and down on the water.

meanings.def: in one direction and then in the opposite direction
examples: She was pacing up and down in front of her desk.

meanings.def: sometimes good and sometimes bad
examples: My relationship with him was up and down.

meanings.def: if you swear up and down that something is true, you say that it is definitely true
working; being used
examples: By that time the new system should be up and running.

meanings.def: appearing in front of somebody in authority for a judgement to be made about something that you have done
examples: He came up before the local magistrate for speeding.

meanings.def: on offer for something
examples: The house is up for sale.

meanings.def: being considered for something, especially as a candidate
examples: Two candidates are up for election.

meanings.def: willing to take part in a particular activity
examples: We're going clubbing tonight. Are you up for it?

meanings.def: among or almost the best, worst, most important, etc.
examples: It may not have been the worst week of my life but it's up there.
OK, it's not my absolute dream, but it's up there.
These people can’t live without the internet—it’s up there with air and water.

meanings.def: as far as a particular number, level, etc.
examples: I can take up to four people (= but no more than four) in my car.
The temperature went up to 35°C.

meanings.def: not further or later than something; until something
examples: Read up to page 100.
Up to now he's been very quiet.

meanings.def: as high or as good as something
examples: Her latest book isn't up to her usual standard.

meanings.def: physically or mentally capable of something
examples: He's not up to the job.
I don't feel up to going to work today.

meanings.def: doing something, especially something bad
examples: What's she up to?
What've you been up to?
I'm sure he's up to no good (= doing something bad).

idioms.def: to be somebody’s duty or responsibility; to be for somebody to decide
examples: It's not up to you to tell me how to do my job.
Shall we eat out or stay in? It's up to you.

idioms.def: to be of poor quality; to not be very good
examples: His work isn't up to much.
Teachers are up against some major problems these days.
She's really up against it (= in a difficult situation).
The boat bobbed up and down on the water.
She was pacing up and down in front of her desk.
My relationship with him was up and down.
By that time the new system should be up and running.

idioms.def: appearing in front of somebody in authority for a judgement to be made about something that you have done
examples: He came up before the local magistrate for speeding.
The house is up for sale.
Two candidates are up for election.
We're going clubbing tonight. Are you up for it?

idioms.def: among or almost the best, worst, most important, etc.
examples: It may not have been the worst week of my life but it's up there.
OK, it's not my absolute dream, but it's up there.
These people can’t live without the internet—it’s up there with air and water.

idioms.def: as far as a particular number, level, etc.
examples: I can take up to four people (= but no more than four) in my car.
The temperature went up to 35°C.
Read up to page 100.
Up to now he's been very quiet.
Her latest book isn't up to her usual standard.
He's not up to the job.
I don't feel up to going to work today.
What's she up to?
What've you been up to?
I'm sure he's up to no good (= doing something bad).

meanings.def: to or in a higher position somewhere
examples: She climbed up the flight of steps.
The village is further up the valley.

meanings.def: along or further along a road or street
examples: We live just up the road, past the post office.

meanings.def: towards the place where a river starts
examples: a cruise up the Rhine

meanings.def: in one direction and then in the opposite direction along something
examples: I looked up and down the corridor.

meanings.def: an offensive way of being rude to somebody, for example because they have said something that makes you angry

idioms.def: in one direction and then in the opposite direction along something
examples: I looked up and down the corridor.

idioms.def: an offensive way of being rude to somebody, for example because they have said something that makes you angry

meanings.def: directed or moving upwards
examples: an up stroke
the up escalator

meanings.def: cheerful; happy or excited
examples: The mood here is resolutely up.

meanings.def: working
examples: Our system should be up by this afternoon.

meanings.def: to suddenly move or do something unexpected
examples: He upped and left without telling anyone.

meanings.def: to increase the price or amount of something
examples: The buyers upped their offer by £1 000.

meanings.def: to increase the level of something, especially your demands or the risks in a situation
examples: This year tournament organizers have upped the ante by offering record prize money for the top two teams.

meanings.def: to improve the level at which you can compete, especially in a sport
examples: She's really upped her game since she joined the tennis club.
With these two snazzy new restaurants opening up, the other eating places in the area are going to have to up their game.

meanings.def: to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else
examples: He upped sticks and went back to France.

idioms.def: to increase the level of something, especially your demands or the risks in a situation
examples: This year tournament organizers have upped the ante by offering record prize money for the top two teams.

idioms.def: to improve the level at which you can compete, especially in a sport
examples: She's really upped her game since she joined the tennis club.
With these two snazzy new restaurants opening up, the other eating places in the area are going to have to up their game.

idioms.def: to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else
examples: He upped sticks and went back to France.

meanings.def: increasing or improving
examples: Business confidence is on the up.

meanings.def: becoming more and more successful
examples: The club has been on the up and up since the beginning of the season.

meanings.def: honest; legal
examples: The offer seems to be on the up and up.

meanings.def: the mixture of good and bad things in life or in a particular situation or relationship
examples: Every business has its ups and downs.
Business confidence is on the up.
The club has been on the up and up since the beginning of the season.
The offer seems to be on the up and up.

idioms.def: the mixture of good and bad things in life or in a particular situation or relationship
examples: Every business has its ups and downs.

meanings.def: higher; upwards; towards the top of something
examples: upland
upturned
upgrade
uphill
